scenes.location: HELLAS BASIN MARS EASTERN RIM DAY 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast, rust-colored plain beneath a pink sky. A smudge o mountains on the horizon. We hold on the hypnotic beauty the emptiness. It could almost be a photograph. ...a faint dust devil in the distance - swirling into for and disappearing within seconds. The camera EASES BACK. The move is barely detectable unti something breaks the bottom of the frame - a gnarled tang of metal, half-buried, covered with over half a century’s dust. Cyrillic script. A Soviet flag. It’s the Russian Mars 2 Lander, which failed to deploy it parachute and slammed into the ground 50 years ago - the first man-made object to touch Mars’ surface. Then, breaking the top of the frame, a hundred miles away from us, a bright flare in the sky descends obliquely. As breaks the frame - a RESOUNDING CHORD - uplifting and dangerous - a sternum-rattling chain of notes, as though music is willing this object into being. The flare fades until all that is left is a small, dark speck. It continues to descend rapidly until - coinciding with another chord - a supersonic parachute deploys. We CUT TO MUCH CLOSER as, a few hundred feet above the surface, a cocoon of balloons inflates and envelops the speck. The parachute disconnects and wafts away. The ballooned object begins a free fall. It hits the gro bouncing high up again and into a succession of smaller parabolas, until it finally comes to a rest. The balloons deflate. Within is a landing pod, a conical vessel with a rounded bottom scorched by the entry. Mechanical arms extend outwards from the sides to right t pod, so the cone is facing up. The cone splits into three separate plates which rotate outward and down, like the petals of a blossoming flower. REVEALING a ROVER - a six-wheeled chassis mounted with robotic hardware. It has two logos: NASA and VISTA. With a deep, guttural note from the sax, the rover’s “eye a 360 degree camera at the end of an extended rod - rises from the hardware to survey the landing zone. The eye til up, as if awakening. We CUT TO the Eye’s view - the distant horizon. The song reaches its crescendo. Then abruptly stops, taking us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rover view of the horizon on a massive screen above 1 rows of room-wide desks covered with monitors, TECHNICIAN SCIENTISTS, and ENGINEERS behind each. Adjacent to the rover view is a digital map of Mars focus on the Hellas Basin with a marker for the rover’s locatio (and other surface robots and hardware), as well as a sec graphic showing Mars in its entirety and the position of multiple objects orbiting it. In the upper right-hand corner are two timecodes marking Earth and Mars times to the hundredth of a second:

dialogues.speaker: MARS 114.52 13
dialogues.text: Here on Earth, it is JUNE 16th, 2025, three and a half ye out from the scheduled crew launch to Mars. We CUT TO Flight Director ALVIN BARRIS (early 50s), and MARTHA HIRSCH (mid 40s), the Mission Control Director. Bo wear headsets. Low-key and workaday in manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proceed to landing zone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Go transmission.

dialogues.speaker: COMMS
dialogues.text: Command sent. E.T.A for transmission 9 minutes, 2 seconds. E.T.A. to target: 2 hours, 12 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Copy. HAB 1 landing countdown remains on schedule for T-minus 33 hours, 35 minutes. We CUT TO the rear of the room where we find LAZ INGRAM ( British), the founder and CEO of VISTA, the private space exploration company teamed with NASA on the venture. He’s staring at the massive screen, arms folded. Laz has the bearing of a man in cool command. He’s a visionary who, like all visionaries, suffers from impatie but does not suffer fools. INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 4 PRETESH KHATTAK (40s, Pakistani-American, the Chief Engin is with his team of engineers, including: MIN ZHOU (Asian American, 30s), VIVEK (Indian-American, 30s), GREG (beefy white, 20s), and WEI (Asian-American, 20s). They're watching the rover feed on a large mounted screen listening to the audio from Mission Control.

dialogues.speaker: COMMS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Feed incoming. A moment later, we see the view pan 90 degrees to another part of the horizon. The assembled watch with awe.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Give me high res and I.R.

dialogues.speaker: COMMS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Commands on deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay everyone, back to work. We've got data dumps coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a line of tire tracks in the fine dust, until w arrive at the ROVER. We come around front and see the tra extending to the landing module in the distance. The rover’s eye tilts down toward the soil. A mechanical swings out with a small drill at the end. The arm lowers the drill to the surface, whereupon the bi begins to spin, then descends into the soil. Its whirring the screech of pulverized rock the only sounds from here the horizon. We hear another mechanical sound: THE ROAR OF A CHAINSAW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on a CHAINSAW biting into ice. CUT TO a WIDE SHOT to see a parka-clad MAN with the saw a the center of a large, frozen lake. There’s a snowmobile him and a HUSKY darting around nearby. CLOSER on the man, as he pushes the cut ice through, and water from the lake bubbles up through the hole. The man is TOM HAGERTY. He’s 52 but more fit than men 20 years his junior. A peppered beard dominates his face. There’s a matter-of-factness about him, a sureness and efficiency to his every movement. He fixes bait to a hook. Lowers the line into the hole wi rod. Props the rod up with a forked stick. Takes a moment look around at the desolate surface of the lake. It never gets old - the sublime. The husky starts to bark. Hagerty glances at the dog, who barking in the direction of another ice hole about thirty yards away. The pole is quivering on its stick. Hagerty makes his way over. Starts to reel in the line. T catch breaks the surface. A large rainbow trout. He unhoo the fish and heads back toward the snowmobile. TIGHT on Hagerty gutting the fish, the blood spilling on the white snow. He tosses some of the innards to the husk who hungrily devours them in a couple bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT CORDINE (50s) - the NASA LIAISON - is doing a stan interview with a news team.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: The rover will confirm our soil composition estimates and give us a ground-up view of the landing. But tomorrow, that’s when interplanetary colonization really becomes tangible... We CUT TO the coverage filling the screen. The chyron rea Bob Cordine - NASA Mars Mission Director. CORDINE (CONT’D) By landing the HAB 1 module, we're putting the first technology on Mars that can support human life. The tests we do on HABs 1 and 2 - they’1l improve the subsequent HABs our crew will call home. HOLLY O'KEEFE (late 20s), Head of VISTA P.R. - to the

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Got what you need?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: We’re good. Thank you. As the Producer shakes hands with Cordine--

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: (to Cordine) Plane’s waiting. Cordine’s ASSISTANT escorts Cordine off.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (to Holly) When do I get Laz?  10

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I gave you Cordine, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Cordine isn’t news. Laz is news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Laz again, looking at the big screen.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laz. Laz looks to Alvin, who is pointing to Laz’s ASSISTANT ov by the door. She’s tapping her wrist. Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUREN GUTIERREZ-HOLT (Latina, late 30s, VISTA’s Program Director), parka-clad, on her phone. She personifies competence and authority. It’s very windy. There’s a HELICOPTER in the background, CHOPPER PILOT beside it. Sh has to shout to be heard above the wind.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What was that? She covers the phone so it’s blocked from the wind.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. Earliest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz in the back talking to the speaker phone. He’s stuck bumper-to-bumper traffic on the highway. There is no one the driver's seat. The car is driving itself.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Maggie’s adamant.  11

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: There’s nothing I can do about the weather.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Does tomorrow give you enough time to get back?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Depends how long it takes me to convince him.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Say again. Gusts of wind are tearing across the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’11 call you when I have the yes. She ends the call. Approaches the CHOPPER PILOT who was waiting for her to get off the phone. LAUREN (CONT’D) You sure we can’t try to beat the blizzard?

dialogues.speaker: CHOPPER PILOT
dialogues.text: Hundred percent.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: (pointing up) The sky’s crystal clear.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean shit in Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagerty and picking up. the Husky are minding the ice holes. The wind is Hagerty looks toward the sky, now beginning to fill with an oncoming front of clouds. Decides it’s bette not to remain out here, exposed. TIME CUT to fish to the husky jumps edge of the Hagerty packing up the poles and strapping the back of the snowmobile. He starts the engine. The onto the back sled. Hagerty drives toward the lake. The wind intensifies, snow beginning to slant down from the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cordine is already on the plane. Laz climbs aboard.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Bob.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: We could’ve come in the same car.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We could've. As Laz settles into a seat not facing Cordine and uncaps waiting bottle of water--

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: I want to talk about Hagerty. Laz ignores him. As he retrieves a sleeping pill and wash it down with the water, the JET PILOT boards--

dialogues.speaker: JET PILOT
dialogues.text: Gonna be a little bumpy on the way out. Fire in the mountains is throwing up some thermals. The two men nod and the pilot heads into the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Near where you live, right?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Wind’s blowing the other way. Laz leans back and closes his eyes. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: I think we should reconsider. Laz keeps his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Lauren’s already en route.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: I just think - from NASA's perspective - Hagerty’s a wild card and we should--  13 Laz opens his eyes and drills Cordine with them.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We had this discussion. Then we had it again. We can go for number three, but I just took an Ambien, and I’m even more stubborn when I’m sleepy. Shall we continue? Cordine says nothing. Laz closes his eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretesh, Min, and Greg are standing in front of the half- built HAB 3 wearing smocks, surgical masks, latex gloves, plastic hair caps. Min shows them a small, rubber washer encircling a valve.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: We ran the raw data again and our shake-bake analysis is off. We favored the wrong results.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: The entry heat could be greater than its combustion limit.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: It’s at least six centimeters under the shield.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: We're worried about free air. Greg pokes his pinky finger into the tube.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Trapped here. Pressure might push it through the lock. She points to a coil of nylon rope in a compartment about foot away from the valve.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: Could get this far. (turns back to him) Which is exactly what I said when I got outvoted by the other departments.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lauren is on her phone, looking out the window at the blizzard. On the other end we hear--

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF ACCOUNTANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: About 46 over because of OT this week.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: How can we make it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glass-walled conference room at the far end of the offi bull-pen. About a dozen DEPARTMENT HEADS gathered.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: I’m working with Sam on materials.

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (HEAD OF PURCHASING)
dialogues.text: Avisma will sell us titanium for 10 percent less. It’s a Russian company, so NASA might not--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You tested the samples?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Pretesh says they’re good.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Alright, I’1l talk to Bob. (shifting focus) Press?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: We've got the big four, plus CNN, Bloomberg, and MSNBC. They all want one-on-- A knock on the glass. Everyone looks over to see Pretesh. mouths “Lauren?” Sam points to the speaker phone and mout “On now.” Pretesh opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Holly?  11.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: Hi Lauren - it’s Tesh. (to the others) I need the room. TIME CUT to Lauren sitting on the edge of the bed. She lo stressed, but not shaken. She glances at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: He’s in the hearing...

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m not saying we have to stop the countdown... CUT BACK to the Conference Room. Pretesh is alone. PRETESH (CONT’D) At least not yet. We should have a better sense in a couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Keep the circle tight. I don’t want this distracting him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closed hearing. Laz and Cordine are seated before the Appropriations Committee. Seated with them is Senator MARGARET SAYERS (early 60s, a Republican from Texas). She Ann Richards, if Richards was a conservative. They’re joi by the NASA ADMINISTRATOR - Cordine’s boss - DEIDRE KENT (early 50s, politically savvy with the polish of a career bureaucrat). The Chairman of Committee is TED WINTHROP (mid 40s, a Republican from Wyoming). Among others are Rep. HAL SCHNE (early 70s, Democrat from Massachusetts) and GAIL OGELBY (late 30s, Republican from Mississippi).

dialogues.speaker: OGELBY
dialogues.text: We're getting into double digits.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNEIDER
dialogues.text: Billions that aren’t going to schools, to infrastructure...  12.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman. Congress has already committed to this plan.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: We approved 70 billion. Not 80. That’s 15 percent over-budget.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: No, it’s right on budget. We told you 85 when we first proposed. You said make it 70 or we get nothing. Sayers discreetly touches Laz’s arm, a signal that says h should soften his tone. But Laz continues--

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all knew we’d have to come back for more. Our plan is still less than half of what my colleagues at NASA were proposing. Deidre shoots a look at Cordine while--

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Our job’s to make sure we’re spending the taxpayers’ money responsibly. Your job is to justify that you are.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman - if we can get back to the specific line items, I believe we can make clear how--

dialogues.speaker: OGELBY
dialogues.text: What is this 92 million for nanotech?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: The FDA approved CRISPR testing on humans, and we need to fund it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHNEIDER
dialogues.text: But is it mission critical?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We can’t fully predict the bio- stressers. Nanotech in the bloodstream gives us the ability to monitor and treat in real-time.  17 13.

dialogues.speaker: OGELBY
dialogues.text: By messing with genetic code.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I'd say improving.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Playing God.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in God, so I’m not in the business of playing him. Sayers, Cordine, and Kent stiffen. Ogelby is not pleased the response.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: We all know God is a she, Laz. A few chuckles. This eases the tension in the room. SAYERS (CONT’D) The best way to see how the money is being spent is with your own eyes. She looks over to Laz with a look that says “step up”.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We hope you’1ll join us for the HAB landing tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: You can meet our top candidate for crew commander. Laz clenches his jaw. Sayers just made a promise he can’t necessarily deliver. We hear the whir of a snowmobile engine and CUT TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The snowmobile is struggling to make headway through the quickly deepening snow. It’s beginning to get dark, and w the storm, visibility is poor. It lurches to a halt. Hagerty tries to restart the engine but it stubbornly coughs, refusing to cooperate.  18 19 14. TIME CUT to Hagerty inspecting the engine. The husky hudd close to the snowmobile to get out of the gusts. Hagerty finds a snapped belt. Pulls it out. Checks his spare part bin, but there’s no backup belt to be found. He unpacks a tent and a shovel from the sled. Starts to d out a spot to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz alone at a secluded table. He’s on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Should I cancel the trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blizzard raging outside. Lauren’s in a booth at a greasy spoon world’s away from the plush restaurant Laz is in.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Tesh says they might need a delay.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know. They have to work out a fix first.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s better if we put the breaks on everything. Takes the rush off you, gives me wiggle room with the clowns out here.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: It didn’t go well?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: It could've gone better.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: What happened?  20 15. He sees a HOSTESS ushering Senator Sayers toward him.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: She's walking toward me.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Game face, Laz. He ends the call. Stands up as Sayers approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: (to the Hostess) Vodka gimlet up. The Hostess nods and departs. As Laz and Sayers sit-- SAYERS (CONT’D) Well - I appreciate your honesty, if not your style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS is setting down a piece of pie with a fresh sp while Lauren's phone is connecting a video call. We see a five-year old girl - Ellie - on the screen. Ther something slightly off about Ellie’s look and the fatigue her voice, but with the image tight on her face and the shakiness of the camera, we’re not sure...

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Hey sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Hi Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You going to bed soon?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’m having some pie first. Lauren shows her the slice of pie with the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want some.

dialogues.speaker: DELL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You already had dessert.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: But now I want pie.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Daddy's right, it’s time for sleep. Give me a kiss. 16. Ellie blows her a kiss. Lauren blows one back. Her husban DELL (early 40s) comes onto the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: How’s it looking? She holds the phone to the window to show the blizzard. DELL (CONT’D) Don’t push him to go earlier than he’s comfortable with.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I see?

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Show her the snow. Lauren holds the phone up to the window again. When she l back at the phone, Ellie has reappeared.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Did you see Santa Claus yet?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Santa Claus?  21 17.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Daddy says you’re at the North Pole.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Close to it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: So you'll see him.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Santa Claus doesn’t exist, darling. Ellie's face contorts. Dell appears back on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: We talked about this.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: She’s five.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’m not going to lie to her.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: We'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Dell...

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: She's crying now. I gotta go. The call ends. Lauren looks at herself in the spoon - an upside down, distorted image of herself. Allows herself t seconds of guilt, then buries it. Sets down the spoon. Picks up her phone. Starts to type something out. During which we hear HOWLING WIND, which t us to-- INT. ALASKA WOODS - HAGERTY’S TENT - NIGHT 21 Hagerty has a SATPHONE linked up to a TABLET DEVICE withi the cramped quarters, his dog taking up half the space intended for a single human.  22 18. On the screen, we see that he’s checking the weather forecast. There’s a large front making its way over north Alaska. He tries to zoom in on it but the website is not responding. He reorients the antenna on the satphone and holds it up toward the top of the flapping tent to get a better signa It works. Zooms in on his location. It looks pretty bad weather-wise. He clicks to a new window. His email. Many of the message are Google alerts for the VISTA/NASA Mars Mission. But am them, he sees an email from Lauren Gutierrez-Holt. The subject is: SEE YOU SOON Opens it. It reads: Since you won’t answer my emails, I’m showing up on your doorstep. Stuck in Fairbanks, but coming your way. Don’t shoot at the chopper. LGH ON Hagerty, brow furrowed in the blue glow of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: This level of funding doesn’t happen without oversight.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: You can’t outsource and micromanage at the same time. We promised faster and cheaper, and you promised autonomy.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Within reason.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Congress is slowing us down.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: You won’t speed anything up by pissing in NASA’s eye at hearings.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Their skin in the game is covering their asses. Mine is getting to Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as my skin.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Yours is the construction jobs in Houston.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: If all I wanted was pork, there’s a helluva lot of easier ways to kill a pig.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I can’t get us there when we’re 15 billion short. I’m spending way too much time and effort--

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Deal with it. There’s no Michelangelo without the Medicis.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: The Medicis were smart enough to buy the paint and get the fuck out Michelangelo's way. She starts to cut her last piece of steak in half.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: I would never tell you how to build a rocket. My expertise is Washington. I’1l get you the money. But that means rolling out the red carpet tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: The landing could be delayed. Off her look--

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a technical problem. There's a valve washer that--

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Then you better get me Hagerty.  23 24 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagerty emerges from the tent with the husky. The snow is deep but falling lightly now. The wind has died down. TIME CUT to him crouched over a propane stove. He holds b ends of the snapped belt over the flame, melting the rubb then presses them together, fusing them. Holds the fused portion over the flame once again, pressing the bond toge with his gloved hands. Then pushes the belt into the snow solidify the bond. TIME CUT to Hagerty fitting the belt back into the engine The sky is clear now. He hears rotor blades. Looks up thr the tree branches and sees a helicopter dart by overhead. TIME CUT to Hagerty on the snowmobile, priming the fuel p then starting the ignition. The machine sputters to life. hops off and inspects the engine. The belt is working. Cl the cover lid and remounts the snowmobile. It lurches for through the deep snow. EXT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - DAY 24 A couple hours later. As Hagerty emerges from the woods i a clearing, we see a small cabin ahead - a modest abode t looks like a collision of the 19th and 21st centuries. Th structure itself could be out of a Jack London novel. But roof is covered with solar arrays and a large satellite d and antennas. Nearby are half a dozen 30-foot-tall, moder looking wind turbines. A few dozen yards from the cabin is the helicopter we saw earlier. Lauren is standing beside it in a big parka. She walks toward Hagerty as the snowmobile comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Thought you might've bailed.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Got caught in the blizzard. He retrieves the frozen trout from the snowmobile -- HAGERTY (CONT’D) Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I could eat.  25 21. INT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - MAIN ROOM - DAY 25 TIGHT on the filleted trout frying in a pan. We pull back see Hagerty at the stove, Lauren at small table. The two-room cabin is tidy. Essentials only. But in one corner is a computer station with several monitors. Top o the line equipment.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I emailed so many times, I grew calluses.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I read all of them.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you answer?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Didn't know if you were serious or just testing the waters.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Well I hope me flying to your doorstep shows how serious we are. Hagerty plates the fish and brings it to Lauren.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: What about Cordine?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Approved.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: He must've put up a fight.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Laz always wins the important ones. That’s why I work for him.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: So how does this work?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: In person. You fly back with me.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I’m not a wine and dine guy.  26 22.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: The head of the Appropriations Committee is coming in.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You need to show me off.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: It’s a few handshakes.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Before I’ve said yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’m an optimist.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You know what my demand will be.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Laz is prepared to address that.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Will I get a yes or a or no?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You have to talk to him yourself. I won’t speak on his behalf. Hagerty cocks his head with deliberation. Then--

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You eat. I’11l pack. On Lauren - relief. Hagerty disappears into the bedroom. INT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - BEDROOM - DAY 26 A fork scrapes across the plate in the other room as Hage packs a duffel with clothing. He takes a couple shirts do from hangers on a pole which stretches above the single b Among the shirts is a NASA flight jacket. He looks at the insignia for a moment. Resumes packing.  27 28 29 30 31 32 23. EXT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - DAY 27 The helicopter rotors swirl to life, kicking up billows o snow beneath. It lifts off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagerty and Lauren in the back, the husky crammed in too. Hagerty looks out the window, as the pristine Alaskan landscape stretches beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In stark contrast to the snowy peaks - the arid Santa Mon mountains. Smoke is billowing upwards from a ridge- line. the distance, we see a private plane making a wide turn t position itself for final approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is beneath the fuselage of the plane. We see t plane’s shadow appear over the runway, get closer, then h the squelch of the tires, as they contact the ground with puffs of burnt rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Electric Minivan pulls through a security gate at the entrance of a massive building that stretches for a quart of a mile. The VISTA logo in three-story letters along th side. The van parks in a space next to the entrance. Laz, Sayers, Cordine, and Winthrop get out. Laz’s ASSISTANT is waiting. Holds open the door as they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach a set of double doors. Above them is a sign which reads: BUILD FACILITY. Laz holds his phone up to a scanner. The doors unlock with a click. As Laz opens the door, we hear the hum of machines, a beeping forklift, me against metal, a symphony of construction.  33 34 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME WIDE SHOT from above, as the foursome make their down a central corridor. The room is vast. One area is dedicated to satellites. Another to the HAB 3 build. A prototype section for the Lander/Mars-Ascent Vehicle (LMA An air-lock portion with engineers in sterilized jumpsuit and hoods doing post-assembly cleaning and stress testing laser cutting and welding section. And at the far end of the room - dominating an entire sid the assembly of a massive rocket. INT. PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 34 Pretesh and Min are showing Alvin a copy of the valve--

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: When we changed the washer from metal to rubber, we did three shake and bakes. Two were within the margin, one wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: How does a red flag like that--

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: You were pushing us on the launch.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: (more diplomatic) Everyone was under pressure. I know you were too.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Give me odds.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: 8 to 1.2 percent catastrophic.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: What’s the fix?

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: We can’t get inside with the arm, so our focus is entry angle.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: My team’s crunching numbers.  35 25.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: (to Pretesh) Freeze the countdown?

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: We could use more time.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Alright. I’1l freeze it. (as he exits) Get me within the margin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayers and Winthrop are dwarfed by the massive rocket the are standing near, gazing at it. Laz and Cordine are a fe yards away talking to Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: When do I get to meet Hagerty?

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: They're in the air now.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: I want a picture with him. Next to one of these.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: I’m sure we can make that happen. Laz and Cordine approach them as Alvin walks off.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Countdown’s frozen.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: There’s a valve we're taking a look at. Our engineers are working on the problem.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: We talking hours, or...

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Hopefully. Might be days.  26

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: (to Sayers) I’ve got to be back for the leadership caucus Thursday morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We'll do our best.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: (to Winthrop) These sort of things are common.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: (to Laz) Seems serious.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Everything’s serious 80 million miles from earth.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: I'd like to pray. Winthrop takes Sayers’ hand. He means an actual prayer. They're all a little taken aback by it. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Bob? Cordine takes Winthrop’s other hand, going with the flow. WINTHROP (CONT’D) (to Laz) I know you’re not a believer...but if you'll indulge me. Sayers shoots a look to Laz. Time to play nice. Laz takes Sayers’ and Cordine’s hands to complete the circle. Winth bows his head and closes his eyes. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Dear heavenly father... Sayers and Cordine follow suit, bowing their heads and closing their eyes. Laz keeps his open. We start to hear deep drone from the baritone sax...  36 37 38 39 27. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Please give your guidance and blessing to the engineers... INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 36 Pretesh, Min, and a team of six other engineers in a heat discussion. Greg finishes an equation on a dry erase boar then Min crosses something out, pointing to an entry-angl diagram--

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...that they might be enlightened with your infinite wisdom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin approaches Martha and says something. She speaks in the headset. We CUT TO to the big screen where we see the countdown clock FREEZE.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...that this delay be brief, and we proceed soon with the mission at hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly is briefing several news camera crews and a dozen reporters on the delay. One of the reporters asks how lon the delay we be. Holly says she doesn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...-So that with the world’s eyes on us, we can show what gifts you have endowed us with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hagerty’s POV out the window, a moonless sky filled with stars above a bank of clouds stretching to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ..-And continue on our path into the magnificent universe you have created...  40 41 42 43 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT of the four linking hands from above. Tiny in relation to the booster rocket. The drone gets louder.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SAXOPHONE PLAYER is playing the baritone sax that we've heard throughout the episode thus far. Circular breathing Cheeks and veins straining, eyes closed, sweat on the bro He’s swaying back and forth slowly, as he wills the unbro drone into being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the drone continues, we see the ISS serenely orbiting earth, passing from day into night, the sun disappearing behind the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drone is replaced with a SWISHING sound. KAYLA FORD (early 40s, African-American) is floating in m gravity looking out the window. Her face lit up by the su blue reflection on earth.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Hank. HANK (mid 50s) is working at the other end of the compartment. He looks over.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You can see that fire in the Santa Monica mountains. He floats over. Looks out the window. Kayla points.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Right there.  44 45 46 29.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I see it.

dialogues.speaker: KAYLA
dialogues.text: Big one, huh? We CUT TO their POV and see the west coast of North Ameri below, major metropolises, a web of bright lights, Los Angeles dominating. Just to the north of the city is a st of glowing fire lines, reddish orange in contrast to the yellow-white electric light. Fingers of smoke stretch for twenty miles to the east. As we slowly push in on the tan of fire lines and smoke, we hear the sound of a raging a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty foot flames. Trunks and branches snapping and crackling. The relentless violence of nature. EXT. LAZ’S MANSION - NIGHT 45 An electric minivan winds up the driveway of a sprawling Italian villa. We can see the orange glow of the forest f in the far distance behind the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID, Laz's butler, shows Hagerty and Lauren into a larg living room. Everything is packed up in boxes. The walls floors are bare. Most of the furniture is pushed to one s of the room along with the boxes and rolled up rugs, exce for one sofa and two chairs placed in the center. A bubbl wrapped Warhol self-portrait is leaned up against one wal upside-down. Laz is sitting on the sofa. He doesn’t stand when Hagerty Lauren enter.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Forgive the appearance.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Moving out or moving in?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Out.  30.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Not the fire...

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Divorce.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Been there.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: (re the chairs) Please. Hagerty and Lauren sit in the chairs opposite the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why Alaska?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Where my mother grew up.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Back to your roots.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Not because Bob shit-canned you. Hagerty looks to Lauren. What can she do? Laz is Laz.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He gave me his version. I want yours.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: NASA’s plan was too convoluted. Too expensive. They were never going to get it off the ground. I was vocal. That rubbed Bob the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: There’s a political element to bringing you back. You’1l have to play nice this time.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Bob must've wanted someone still on the inside.  31.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: He did. I don’t. But I need someone with a NASA pedigree.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: With more allegiance to you.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Two birds, one commander.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You know my ask.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I can’t give you final say on the crew. A lot of people will want to weigh in.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: They can weigh in all they want, but this is over two years there and back. I need to pick the team.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I‘1l do everything I can to protect your choices. But I’m not the sole sovereign here, as much as I'd like to be.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: When the terms aren’t clear, it gets messy. I learned that the hard way.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: If you want the command, you’re going to have to place the same faith in me as I’m prepared to place in you. They hold each other’s gaze, then abruptly--

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Lauren) Where are we putting him up?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Four Seasons.  47 32.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I hate the Four Seasons. (to Hagerty) You can stay in the guest house. Laz exits without a word, no hand shake. Hagerty and Laur are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Ball's in your court. Hagerty gets up and walks over to the Warhol painting.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His wife is a collector. Ex-wife. Hagerty considers the painting for a moment, then--

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: The engineers still at it?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Until there’s a fix.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I want to stop by.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Is that a yes?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It’s a maybe. INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 47 Hagerty and Lauren with Pretesh, along with Min, Wei, Gre and two other engineers. All the engineers look exhausted The dry erase board is filled edge to edge with hastily d diagrams and complex equations. Pretesh holding up a VISTA mug at an angle, using it as a model for the aeroshell.  33.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: We reduce heat back here... (pointing to the bottom edge) But the increase here takes us out of the margin.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You could rotate during entry. Hagerty takes the mug, using it to illustrate. HAGERTY (CONT’D) Distribute heat across the rim.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: Problem is, it could twist the parachute cords.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Not if you stop rotation just before deployment.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: We can’t predict how the atmosphere will affect rotation speed. If we pre-program incorrectly... Illustrating with the mug--

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be perfect. The torque of the parachute will stabilize even if you have a little spin. Worked like a gem on Apollo 20. Look... He goes over to a computer. Pulls up a video. Everyone cr around. We see footage of a re-entry taken from a high altitude drone, an orange glow on a turning capsule. HAGERTY (CONT’D) X-axis spin - unplanned. Right here - I pump the thruster. Manual, so nowhere close to perfect...still spinning a little...and here... We see the chutes deploy, the capsule jerks from the tens spins slightly in the other direction then settles, the s stopping.  48 34. HAGERTY (CONT’D) Boom. A little jerky for a second, but stable.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: You had more air resistance.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I’m not an engineer. I’m just going from experience.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: Let’s do the math. As the engineers get to work, Hagerty turns to Lauren.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Go get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Go home. I'll do the sprint. You do the marathon. She nods, squeezes his hand, then exits. INT. LAUREN’S HOME - BEDROOM - DAY 48 Early morning. Dell is asleep in bed. We hear a door open Footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay little one - here we go. Dell stirs, squinting at the morning light. Looks over at other side of the room. We see Ellie being lifted by a nanny - INEZ (20s) - froma medical bed into a high-tech, child-sized wheelchair, transferring a catheter tube connected to the bed to a so on the chair. Ellie has a swollen abdomen and weak limbs. has advanced Gaucher’s disease. Dell sits up.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Morning Inez.  49 35.

dialogues.speaker: INEZ
dialogues.text: Morning. INT. LAUREN’S HOME - UPSTAIRS - DAY 49 49 Dell - showered and dressed - lightly knocks on a door. H got a mug of coffee in the other hand. Without waiting fo response, he opens the door to find Lauren in her home office. The walls are covered with Mars maps and several large calendars with key mission dates filled in. Lauren folding a blanket and placing it on a small sofa where we a couple of pillows.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake her when I came in.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: (letting it slide) Inez has breakfast ready.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’ve got to change and get to the office. (re the coffee) That for me? He holds out the mug. She takes it, has a sip.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Can you go in a little late today?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Winthrop’s here, and the countdown is frozen because--

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: She hasn't seen you in two days.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I know, and it kills me, but I--

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Alright, forget it.  50 36.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Don’t punish me.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: Punish you?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: For the Santa thing.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I’ll stay for breakfast. Dell says nothing. His version of a truce. She sets the coffee down, gives him a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you. She exits. Dell picks up the mug she left behind. INT. LAUREN’S HOME - DAY 50 Lauren is feeding Ellie with a spoon. Dell silently eats the other side of the table. Inez washes dishes.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Can I try?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Lauren scoops up a spoonful of Ellie’s oatmeal, then wrap Ellie’s hand around the spoon. It takes some effort for E to bring the spoon to her lips, but she does. LAUREN (CONT’D) Great. Lauren wipes the excess oatmeal off of Ellie’s mouth. Tak the spoon and scoops up some more oatmeal. Places the spo back in Ellie’s hand. But this time, she drops the spoon before it gets to her mouth. Inez, hearing the clatter, starts to come over.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s alright. I got it.  51 52 37. Lauren picks up the spoon. Wipes it off with the napkin. Scoops another spoonful of oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Let’s try again. Places the spoon back in Ellie’s hand. Keeping her hand wrapped around Ellie’s--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here - I’1l help you. On Dell - who can’t help but be moved by the tenderness Lauren is exhibiting toward their daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winthrop is in the middle of giving an interview to a cam crew. Holly and Sayers looking on.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: When you’re here, and you see hundreds of people - the magnitude of it - I’m convinced that America will get there before the Chinese... As Winthrop continues, we CUT TO Sayers leaning into Holl ear, sotto voce--

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: You line up as many as you can. There’s nothing he loves more than free press. Well, except baby Jesus. Holly has to stifle her laugh. INT. VISTA HQ - BULL-PEN - LAUREN’S CUBICLE - DAY 52 Lauren and Cordine mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: What’s the hesitation?  38.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: He wants final say on crew.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: You see - this is exactly why I didn’t -

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Laz told him no.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: The guy’s not a team player. I can list three other candidates who--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: We can’t second guess every decision like this, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lauren. They both look over to see LAUREN’S ASSISTANT nod toward central corridor. Laz is approaching. Before he even gets Lauren’s cubicle--

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: What’s Pretesh saying?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: They're getting there.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: We were just discussing Hagerty. Laz glances at Lauren to get a sense of how the conversat was going. Not well is the sense he gets. CORDINE (CONT’D) There’s no way he gets final say on crew selection.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I told him you--

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: And I don’t care if I sound like a broken record. I still have serious doubts about--  39.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I’ve got a 4-billion-dollar HAB we're trying to keep from blowing up. This is the discussion you want to be-- Cordine calmly, firmly interrupts--

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: You've been given a great deal of freedom, but that’s your privilege, not your right. I can veto. I am the safeguard. So if I want to discuss this a third time, and a fourth and a fifth, that’s what we'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winthrop doing another interview.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How close are the Chinese?

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: They've got Russia and India helping - a lot of tech and financial resources. But we’re about to start crew selection. I don’t think the Chinese are anywhere near that stage.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Does that mean a crew commander’s already been chosen?

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: I’ve been told it’s probably going to be Tom Hagerty, which I think would be an excellent choice. CUT TO Holly and Sayers, both dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: He didn’t...

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: He did.  54 40. INT. VISTA HQ - BULL-PEN - LAUREN’S CUBICLE - DAY 54 Laz, Cordine, and Lauren in the thick of it.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: You wanted a NASA guy. I’m getting you a NASA guy.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Former NASA.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We’re all pros, Bob. You can work with someone you fired.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: He doesn’t respect authority.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Because he was right. You were dragging your asses. During which Lauren gets a text message.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: This is still a NASA venture.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: It’s a joint venture.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: The Congressman just announced Hagerty.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: On camera. The two men are stunned for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Well that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Did you put him up to it?  55 41.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I’m a prick, but I’m not a two- faced prick. INT. LAZ’S GUEST HOUSE - DAY 55 Hagerty is in the living room watching coverage of Winthr on TV. He looks as though he’s barely slept.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...expect to meet with him today, and we'll go from there. Hagerty numb. The coverage CUTS TO a NEWS ANCHOR--

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Colonel Tom Hagerty commanded two missions and oversaw the astronaut training program before leaving NASA three years ago... We see footage of Hagerty on a moon walk. NEWS ANCHOR (CONT’D) He’s conducted more space flights than any American, second only to Sasha Illyich of Russia... There’s a knock at the door. During the coverage...

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It’s open. It’s David, the butler.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Car’s here for you.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Let me take Apollo for a quick walk first.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whenever you’re ready. As David leaves, Hagerty crouches down and takes Apollo's face in his hands.  56 57 42.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Leash or no leash? Apollo swivels his head free and barks. HAGERTY (CONT’D) Alright - no leash. Hagerty’s cell phone vibrates on the coffee table. He loo at it, decides to ignore. Turns off the TV instead. Heads the door, as the phone continues to vibrate-- HAGERTY (CONT’D) Come on, boy. INT. VISTA HQ - HALLWAY/PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 56 We FOLLOW Laz, as he briskly makes his way down the hallw to Pretesh’s office. Opens the door. The camera whirls ar to Pretesh and his team, all turning to look at the boss.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Tell me there’s progress.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: We may have something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE shot of Hagerty walking slowly along the road - all gated houses on lush estates. Sprinklers going full force one of them. Apollo is trotting along ahead, sniffing her and there. In the distance we can see the smoke rising fr the Santa Monica mountain fire. A HUMMER-ESQUE vehicle barrels down the road, blaring mus and whizzing past Hagerty and his dog. Hagerty watches th vehicle disappear over the crest. He turns back to Apollo, who scampers around a bend and o of sight. After a few moments, he hears barking, then growling. He whistles for Apollo, but the dog does not co when called. The barking and growling continue. Hagerty picks up his p to a fast walk. As he rounds the bend, he sees Apollo squ off with three COYOTES. They’re smaller than Apollo but h power in numbers.  58 43.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Apollo! But it does no good. The posturing continues. Hagerty wal closer, tentatively, hoping to scare the coyotes away. He claps his hands loudly as he yells out-- HAGERTY (CONT’D) Go on now! Go on! But this snaps them from defensive to offensive. One of t coyotes lunges at Apollo. Apollo claws and bites, sending of the coyotes darting a few yards away, but just as it retreats, another one attacks. Apollo has a tougher time this one, and, sensing weakness, the first and third coyo pounce as well. Apollo is thrashing about, trying to fend them off, but h can’t cover all sides at once. The coyotes are snapping a his legs, going for his throat when they can. Apollo gets pinned to the ground. Hagerty acts instinctively. He whips off his pullover and wraps it around one of his forearms. Heads into the fray. Uses the padded arm to swipe at the coyotes. One of them locks onto his covered arm with its jaw. Hagerty swings b and forth to shake him off. The coyote scampers off. He t his attention to the other two, whacking until they roll of Apollo and trot away into the brush. Apollo whimpers o the ground, bloodied by gashes. EXT. LAZ’S MANSION - DAY 58 Hagerty carries Apollo toward the front gate. It’s no sma feat - the dog weighs well over a hundred pounds. But adrenalin has kicked in, and his only thought is getting help. When he gets to the intercom, he presses the call button with his elbow. A moment later--

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Hagerty?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Bring the car down. Now.  59 60 61 44. INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 59 Apollo squirms as Hagerty and a VET’S ASSISTANT hold him on an examination table. The VETERINARIAN gives Apollo a in the hindquarter. Apollo lets out a high- pitched whine Hagerty runs a hand along Apollo’s snout.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It’s okay, buddy. It’s alright. In a few moments, Apollo slackens from the sedation.

dialogues.speaker: VETERINARIAN
dialogues.text: There's a couple deep bites - here...and here. We’1l have to stitch those up. I'll want to doa rabies and tetanus treatment too.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Colonel. The DRIVER has entered. Holds out a phone.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Ingram’s office. Say they’ve been trying to reach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayers is introducing Winthrop to Alvin and Martha. Laure on her phone about twenty yeard away, keeping an eye on t

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: He’s getting antsy. I need you to spend some face time with him.
INT. VET’S OFFICE - WAITING ROOM - DAY 61 Hagerty on the Driver’s cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: When we’re done here.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: How long?  62 63 45.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Could be a while.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: I know he jumped the gun. I’m sorry for that. We’re not trying to corner you.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It’s not about him. I won’t leave my dog. He’1l sense if I’m gone.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Please Tom - do me this favor. INT. PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 62 The office is crammed with people now, including Laz, Pretesh, Min, Wei, Vivek, Greg, Alvin, the Mission Geolog and several Engineers. With a paucity of chairs, most peo are standing. Min is holding up a model of HAB 1, slowly rotating it.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: All we need is about sixty seconds of relief on this side, so if we-- Cordine enters. People move aside to make room for him in cramped space.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Please. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lauren escorts Hagerty toward the large booster rocket, w Winthrop and Sayers are waiting with a photographer. Wint lights up at seeing Hagerty.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Colonel, it’s an honor. As they shake hands-- WINTHROP (CONT’D) Not everyday I shake hands with a man who’s been to the moon. Just wish my son could be here with me.  46

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: Studying astrophysics at M.I.T.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Great program.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Too far from home. And chock full of liberals. But if you want to study space, you make sacrifices. Winthrop laughs. Hagerty forces a smile. WINTHROP (CONT’D) I'd like to take a picture, if you don’t mind - to send to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Of course. As Hagerty and Winthrop walk toward the rocket--

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Maggie tells me I opened my trap too soon about you coming on.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: No worries.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Well, sure as heck hope you say yes. I don’t want to allocate all this money to build a ship that doesn’t have the best skipper.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Right there is great. Winthrop throws his arm around Hagerty with a big, toothy smile. Hagerty manages half a smile. Camera flashes. PHOTOGRAPHER (CONT’D) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: (to Hagerty) So tell me - what was it like? The first time you set foot on the moon? What was your very first thought?  64 47.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Disappointment. Winthrop’s face falls. Sayers and Lauren stiffen.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Disappointment...?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t Mars. And it could've been. If NASA spent its money right.

dialogues.speaker: SAYERS
dialogues.text: I think what the Colonel is trying to say is--

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Don’t sugar-coat it, Maggie. (to Hagerty) It’s refreshing to hear the truth. Sign of a good leader. INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 64 Further into the presentation. Pretesh is pointing to a m of Mars on the wall. Sundry equations and diagrams popula the dry erase board.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: The new entry angle means we'll have to put down here - the Cerberus Plains - either landing site three or nine.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: How’s the soil situation?

dialogues.speaker: GEOLOGIST
dialogues.text: It’s not as mineral or water rich, but it’s flat, open terrain.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Is there enough water to test the fuel generators?  48.

dialogues.speaker: GEOLOGIST
dialogues.text: We only got half a meter down so it’s tough to say. Our estimate is yes. Barely.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: But this puts us close to our margin on the valve.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Just close?

dialogues.speaker: VIVEK
dialogues.text: Point zero six. All eyes on Laz, waiting for his decision. He looks down the ground, considering, then back up at Cordine.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I'm willing to roll the dice if you are, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: It’s your call.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Our call. Cordine appreciates the respect given him in front of the assembled team.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Let’s roll ‘em. An appreciative nod from Laz. Cordine is stepping up.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: (to Alvin) Program the entry, and let’s get to countdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin and Martha are at their stations. Lauren, Sayers, a Winthrop are behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Navigation.  49. We CUT TO each of the stations as they pipe in.

dialogues.speaker: NAVIGATION
dialogues.text: Primary MPS check. Secondary check.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Propulsion.

dialogues.speaker: PROPULSION
dialogues.text: Thrusters one through six operational.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Software.

dialogues.speaker: SOFTWARE
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Telemetry.

dialogues.speaker: TELEMETRY
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Meteorology.

dialogues.speaker: METEOROLOGY
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (to Alvin) Ready to transmit.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: (to Winthrop) Will you do us the honor, Congressman? Alvin hands Winthrop his headset. As Winthrop puts it on-

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The command is “Go on landing sequence.”

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Now? Alvin nods. Winthrop looks like a kid in a candy store.  66 67 50. WINTHROP (CONT’D) (into the headset) Go on landing sequence.

dialogues.speaker: COMMS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Landing sequence sent.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Countdown is transmission plus 15:52. T-minus 24:17. We see the COUNTDOWN appear on the big screen. CUT TO Laz standing in the back of the room, as he was ne the top of the episode. TIGHT on his finger tapping his b with each second that ticks off the countdown clock. He’s wound up. Abruptly, he makes for the exit. We STAY with him, FOLLOWING from behind. A rapid flurry of sax notes starts to bubble up, the slap of the valves and circular breathing giving it a percussi energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Laz passes by the camera crews--

dialogues.speaker: REPOTER
dialogues.text: Laz... Without stopping he holds up a hand that says “not now.” stay with him as he passes through a set of doors into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music continues. A sea of cubicles. Everywhere he wal he draws glances - he’s the big boss, after all. The musi picking up in pace and intensity, an anxious frenetic fee it. He passes through the lobby and main double door into...  68 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the BRIGHT SUNLIGHT. Keeps walking through the front parking lot, away from the building, away from everyone. notes are furiously fast now. There are satellite trucks parked out front now to cover landing. Laz heads in the opposite direction. He stops about 30 yards away from the entrance. And as he stops, the music abruptly stops too. We finally COME AROUND on him. He’s got his eyes closed. the sun shine down on his face. Breathing. He pulls out his phone. Speed dials. On speaker. A double ring, like they have in the U.K. An ELDERLY WOMAN’S voice answers. It’s a middle class Yorkshire accent.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hallo? Hi mum.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a nice surprise. Her voice is a balm.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Sorry to call so late.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isn't today your big day?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Supposed to be. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh fine. Had our final rehearsal tonight for the Carlisle concert. Everyone’s nervous, of course.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I’m going to have to come see the choir sometime.  69 52.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You'd rather be caught dead than in a church. True.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s a nice program. Vitry and Machaut. Philip gave me one of the featured sopranos.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Let’s have a taste. Over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (laughs) I’m embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: It’s just me.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ'S MOTHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well...okay, but just a little. I haven't done my vocal exercises. She clears her throat, then begins to sing a portion from Guilliame de Machaut’s “La Messe de Nostre Dame.” Her voi is tinny through the phone, but soothing and confident. I measured melody an antidote to the unsettling saxophone assault we heard moments before. Laz sits down on the ground between two cars. Leans his b against a wheel well. Holds the phone between his knees a listens, as though it’s a blood transfusion. As her singing continues, we SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz entering the front doors - calm and re-energized. We with him again, but this time from the front, moving backwards as he moves forward. As he passes through the double-doors to the main bull-pen, additional voices come filling out the full harmony of Machaut’s piece.  70 71 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We retrace the same route as before, but TIME CUTTING to through it faster, the music continuing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz makes his way back inside. Assumes his usual place in back. Lauren approaches.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I’m good. As the music continues we CUT TO a tracking shot of Missi Control staff waiting anxiously. CUT TO half a dozen news cameras pointed at the Mission Control room, one of the cameramen chewing his lip. Over the P.A. --

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Transmission delivery in 5..4..3... We CUT TO Martha and Alvin at their station. MARTHA (CONT’D) 2...1...landing sequence initiated. Countdown to confirmation 9 minutes 14 seconds. Martha leans back in her chair. Alvin remains forward, el on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: Wish the speed of light was about twenty times faster. The music continues as we move through a MONTAGE-- -- Winthrop and Sayers in the back. Sayers staring at the screen. Winthrop’s head bowed in prayer. -- Hagerty looking up at the screen, as still as a statue  54. -- WIDE SHOT outside the control room, where scores of st have gathered to watch on monitors. -- the empty rocket tube, work lights still inside, but n technicians there. -- WIDE SHOT of the long central corridor, devoid of anyo -- Exterior of the VISTA Headquarters, the satellite truc dwarfed by the massive logo. -- Two car mechanics working under the hood of a side- sw Prius in a rundown auto shop on Lincoln Blvd. Another mechanic gets their attention to show them live coverage his phone. -- A homeless man pushing a cart down the sidewalk, a cardboard sign on his back: I HAVE DREAMS TOO. -- People in business attire waiting in line at a food tr in downtown L.A. All watching their phones. -- Third graders in a classroom. All of them watching coverage on a TV that’s been brought into the room. -- Directly above the city of Los Angeles, a clover-leaf highway intersection dominating the center of the frame, every lane jammed with traffic. Slowly PULLING BACK... -- The Santa Monica mountains - raw nature in contrast to urban sprawl of the city. A wisp of smoke. -- A burned-out log in a sea of scorched and naked tree trunks, the remains of the forest fire. A small bird fluttering onto one of the logs - the only bit of color i black and ashen landscape. Then the bird flying off, whipping the camera toward the in a failed attempt to follow it. -- Taking us to the interior of the ISS - Kayla and Hank floating as they stare at a computer screen, the same ima on the big screen at Mission Control. We shift focus from them to a small socket wrench floatin behind them, slowly spinning as it inches across the cabi Which takes us to--  72 73 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HAB 1 ENTRY MODULE floats serenely above the curvatur the red planet below. With several short bursts, the thrusters angle the bottom of the module toward the surfa A burst from a side thruster initiates a gentle rotation. final sequence of bursts stops the angling and rotation, one long burst slows the module down enough to succumb to Mars’ gravity. It begins a gradual descent. We see the faintest glimmer of entry burn start to glow on the lip o the module.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Martha and Alvin at their station, both waiting for th transmission to come through. We can tell from a shift in body posture that it’s arrived. Alvin looks to Martha.

dialogues.speaker: PROPULSION
dialogues.text: Thruster sequence check. Entry angle confirmed at 23.78 degrees. Rotation at 1.14 rpm. INTERCUT between Martha and the following--

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Trajectory.

dialogues.speaker: TRAJECTORY
dialogues.text: On course check, speed: two one zero five with uniform decrease eight nine seven kilometers per second.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Heat readings.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: Variable from 650 to 935 Celsius. CUT TO Pretesh, Vivek, and Min toward the back.

dialogues.speaker: VIVEK
dialogues.text: (to Pretesh) That’s in our zone. Pretesh holds up both hands, fingers crossed on each.  74 75 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HAB 1 module screaming toward the Mars surface, a mas burn glow enveloping the entire craft, strongest on the lowest part of the lip angled most toward the ground. But the atmospheric resistance slows the module, the burn glo starts to reduce, finally disappearing altogether. Then another thruster burst, which slows down the rotation to almost nothing. As it slows, the MUSIC FADES until it is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension is felt by the stillness of the room, people barely breathing.

dialogues.speaker: TRAJECTORY
dialogues.text: Rotation 0.09 rpm... Silence as they wait for the next phase. Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Chute deployment? She waits for a response. MARTHA (CONT’D) Chute deployment? A beat, then--

dialogues.speaker: SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: Parachute deployed. A few people clap, but most don’t. One of them is next to Head of Systems who whispers-- SYSTEMS (CONT’D) Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Eight seconds until secondary chute. On Sayers and Winthrop. Then to Pretesh and his team.

dialogues.speaker: VIVEK
dialogues.text: (to Pretesh) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: VIVEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If the washer had burned, it would've affected the primary chute. I think we’re gonna--

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: Shut up. We’re not down til we’re down.

dialogues.speaker: SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: Secondary chute deployed. We can sense the tension starting to let up in the room. They’re not home free yet, but they survived the burn pha and the chute deployment. The two stages everyone was mos worried about.

dialogues.speaker: TRAJECTORY
dialogues.text: Speed remains constant. Not good. Tension ripples back through the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Repeat trajectory. You said speed is constant?

dialogues.speaker: TRAJECTORY
dialogues.text: Now it’s increasing. Point eight terminal velocity. Point nine...

dialogues.speaker: SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: Erratic rotation.

dialogues.speaker: PROPULSION
dialogues.text: Retro-thrusters have kicked in... We CUT BACK TO Pretesh, Vivek, and Min.

dialogues.speaker: MIN
dialogues.text: Too high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The module is six kilometers above the surface, plummetin fast. Its primary and secondary chutes are tangled, causing it spin wildly, the tangled chutes unable to slow its descen and the thrusters doing little to slow descent at this sp especially at this height and with the erratic spin.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz, Cordine, and Pretesh are standing over Martha and Alvin's shoulders now, staring at their screens.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: The landing thrusters...

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN
dialogues.text: It’s not enough at this speed.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: The rotation’s too variable to counteract.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: Impact in nine...eight...seven... Lauren has walked over to Holly now.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Can we get Laz out of his interviews?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You're killing me.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: How is this good press?

dialogues.speaker: SYSTEMS
dialogues.text: ...three...two...one. A beat, then Martha, trying not to sound defeated--

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Telemetry.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF TELEMETRY
dialogues.text: We've lost contact. A wave of disappointment through the room. These people a all professionals. They’ve seen dozens of launch and land failures, but never one as important as this. On Hagerty, stoic. CUT TO Sayers and Winthrop. She steals a glance at him. H shaking his head.  78 79 59. We CUT TO Laz and Pretesh. Pretesh looks devastated but i trying to keep it together.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t the valve. I’m guessing it was something with the deployment mechanism.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Full diagnostics.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Laz.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We'll land the next one. Lauren and Cordine approach.

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: I‘1l do the press, if you'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Let’s do it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the saxophone, we hear one long, somber note. The ca glides over the Martian red dust, pristine and untouched, angled down so the ground fills the frame. As the note be to taper off, the camera slows, and we see the gnarled wreckage of the HAB, smoldering from the crash. The tatte and scorched parachutes stretching a hundred yards, as th the module were bleeding cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on the Saxophone player, as the tapering note retre into silence. Then he takes a breath, removes the reed an opens the valves, dumping the built up spit onto the grou Over which we hear--

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We can’t predict everything. That’s the nature of space exploration...  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz and Cordine are speaking to a scrum of press.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We try, we fail, we try again.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: But once you send people, if there’s a failure...

dialogues.speaker: CORDINE
dialogues.text: Will people die? Obviously we want to prevent that. But it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: It’s not just possible, it’s probable. Colonizing a new planet is the biggest challenge humanity has ever faced.

dialogues.speaker: CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Even if the cost is human life.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: We're doing this to perpetuate human life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laz and Cordine are walking Sayers and Winthrop out the d to their waiting minivan. They’re mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: Not saying it won’t happen, but it’s a much tougher sell now.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I hope we can count on you.

dialogues.speaker: WINTHROP
dialogues.text: The only thing I’ve learned from politics is never to make promises. (as he climbs in) But get Hagerty out East. My people will be much more amenable to an American hero than a limey billionaire.  82 83 84 61. Being a limey, Laz appreciates the dry humor of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HAB 3 unit. Pretesh is there with his team.

dialogues.speaker: PRETESH
dialogues.text: Let’s dismantle the entire system. Lay it out, piece by piece... INT. LAUREN’S HOME - NIGHT 83 Lauren enters the house, looking exhausted. Makes her way into the living room, where she sees a CONGRATULATIONS si draped above the archway to the dining room, balloons everywhere. Dell waiting for her in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DELL
dialogues.text: I left it up on purpose. Off her look-- DELL (CONT’D) Take this. He hands her a balloon. INT. LAZ’S GUEST HOUSE - NIGHT 84 Hagerty puts a bowl of water on the ground. Apollo, banda and still a bit out of it, laps up the water. Hagerty run hand through his mane. A knock.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: It’s open. Laz enters.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: (seeing Apollo) How’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: A few cuts. He’ll be fine. Laz steps closer to pet him, but Apollo barks.  62. HAGERTY (CONT’D) Doesn’t make friends easily.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Was it just the two of you up north?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Your mother’s not from Alaska. She lived there for less than a year when your grandad was working the rigs in Prudhoe.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Did you check before or after I lied to you?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Before.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you call me out on it?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: You don’t embarrass a man you're trying to convince.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I haven't said yes yet.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Why did you go? Hagerty just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forget I asked. Laz crouches down and lets Apollo sniff his hand. This ti Apollo doesn’t bark and lets Laz pet him.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: The sky. Laz looks up.  63. HAGERTY (CONT’D) When it’s clear - in the winter - you can see it all. Twenty-three hours of night. As cold as space. If I was never gonna get the chance again, it was the next best thing.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Now you’ve got your chance.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Still no final say?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: I can’t promise it any more than you can promise the crew they’11 survive. But I'll do my best. The logic is sound, and Hagerty believes him.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: When do I start?

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: You need to settle things up back home?

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: There’s nothing there I can’t leave behind.

dialogues.speaker: LAZ
dialogues.text: Then tomorrow. We’ll fly you out to D.C. with Bob to rub shoulders. (points) The beard.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: I’1l shave. Without a handshake or farewell, Laz exits. INT. LAUREN’S HOME - BEDROOM - NIGHT 85 Lauren and Dell enter and turn on the light, Lauren holdi balloon. Ellie stirs awake. She’s hooked up in her medica bed.  64.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Hi Mommy. Lauren pierces one of the balloons with her teeth and suc in the helium. With a high-pitched voice--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Hi sweetheart. Mommy’s happy to see you. Ellie bursts into laughter at the sound of her mother’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Again! During which, Dell edges out of the room to let them have some time alone together. With lungs full of more helium-

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: This is what I sounded like - when I was your age. More laughter from Ellie. Then abruptly, matter-of-fact--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Am I going to die? The question catches Lauren off guard, and yet--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: Everybody-- But she still has the helium voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck. She exhales, letting the helium pass from her lungs. Then with a normal voice--

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone dies.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: But will I die soon? Lauren considers for a moment, then - unblinking--  86 65.

dialogues.speaker: LAUREN
dialogues.text: You've already lived longer than you were supposed to. Because you're strong. Ellie weighs this, then - straightforward--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Do the funny sound again. Off Lauren as she sucks in more helium from the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Hagerty’s face in the shower, hot water streamin down from crown to chin. TIME CUT to Hagerty in front of the sink, a circle wiped on the steamed mirror so he can see himself. The BUZZ of clippers as he begins to shave off his beard. TIGHT on the sink, hair falling into the bowl. TIME CUT to Hagerty in the bedroom, completely naked, sta at himself in the full-length mirror. He’s clean shaven n His body is not that of a young man’s anymore - its imperfections amplified by age. But he’s still fit. Stron stature, vulnerable in nakedness. Human. He walks over to a sliding door leading to a terrace, sti naked. Opens it and walks outside, letting the warm, dry California night air envelop his skin. Looks over at the burning orange glow from the Santa Moni Mountains fire in the distance. His focus shifts to the big house, where he sees Laz on t patio looking at the glow from the fire as well. Laz turn him. Hagerty makes no move hide his nakedness. Laz doesn’ show any outward reaction to it. Laz gives him a casual salute, then heads back inside. Hagerty turns his attention back to the sky, in the oppos direction of the fire. From his POV we see a tiny reddish dot in the cloudless n sky. Mars. You have to strain to see it.  BACK ON Hagerty, staring up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: HAGERTY
dialogues.text: Goddamn. BLACK OUT.
